Description: Terracotta cooking stove fragment. A pot-support broken from a cooking-stove. This differs from most in that the pot-rest, which is plain, is placed high on the raised panel, well above the rim of the fire-bowl. It also has the edge of a circular aperture that opened into the bowl itself, probably below rim-level. At the back, the raised edge of the aperture is encircled by a groove made by a finger-tip; above this, rising and falling at an angle on the panel, are two parallel finger-tip grooves. The bowl was probably wheel-made, and the support and panel hand-modelled. Crude orange-red slip on outside. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt with a red and grey core, the inside darkened by use.
Curator's comments: Published (Bailey 2008; Petrie 1886, 42; Şahin 2001, 125, figs 127 and 128:Na 17). Şahin, M. 2001. Hellenistic braziers in the British Museum: Trade contacts between ancient Mediterranean cities. Anatolian Studies 51: 91-132.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3691)
Şahin 2001 / Hellenistic braziers in the British Museum: Trade contacts between ancient Mediterranean cities (p.125, figs 127 and 128:Na 17)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (LA.15) (Phase 3)
